content: Openly Gay Man Elected to Colo. Senate Veteran Colorado LGBT activist Pat Steadman will become the first openly gay man to serve in the Colorado state senate, local news sources report. Steadman won a special vacancy selection open to members of the state Democratic Party on Tuesday. He will replace the outgoing Sen. Jennifer Veiga, the first openly gay person to serve in the state legislature. She resigned the seat to move to Australia with her partner and her partner's family. Two out of the three finalists in this week's special election to replace Veiga were openly gay, reports The Colorado Independent . >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid85476.asp Congratulations.

content: This is where the generation gap between myself and the Colonel becomes evident. My first reaction upon reading this was, "That's cool, but so what?" It's nice that the people of the state of Focus on the Family are willing to overlook a personal matter like this and elect a man to represent them on merit rather than outward BS - but it isn't a life-altering event for me. It's just the way things should be. It has to do with the different realities we grew up in, I suppose. The Colonel grew up in a time when people that he cared about called him evil and satanic for just such an outward thing. I grew up in a time when people look upon gays with a sense of mild disapproval, but eventually come to realize that gays are individuals no more or less "bad" than society at large. It's a difference in perspective. For me equality is just a matter of time. For him, and his generation, equality is nothing short of a miracle.

content: Openly Gay Man Elected to Colo. Senate Veteran Colorado LGBT activist Pat Steadman will become the first openly gay man to serve in the Colorado state senate, local news sources report. Steadman won a special vacancy selection open to members of the state Democratic Party on Tuesday. He will replace the outgoing Sen. Jennifer Veiga, the first openly gay person to serve in the state legislature. She resigned the seat to move to Australia with her partner and her partner's family. Two out of the three finalists in this week's special election to replace Veiga were openly gay, reports The Colorado Independent . >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid85476.asp Congratulations.

content: This is where the generation gap between myself and the Colonel becomes evident. My first reaction upon reading this was, "That's cool, but so what?" It's nice that the people of the state of Focus on the Family are willing to overlook a personal matter like this and elect a man to represent them on merit rather than outward BS - but it isn't a life-altering event for me. It's just the way things should be. It has to do with the different realities we grew up in, I suppose. The Colonel grew up in a time when people that he cared about called him evil and satanic for just such an outward thing. I grew up in a time when people look upon gays with a sense of mild disapproval, but eventually come to realize that gays are individuals no more or less "bad" than society at large. It's a difference in perspective. For me equality is just a matter of time. For him, and his generation, equality is nothing short of a miracle.

content: Openly Gay Man Elected to Colo. Senate Veteran Colorado LGBT activist Pat Steadman will become the first openly gay man to serve in the Colorado state senate, local news sources report. Steadman won a special vacancy selection open to members of the state Democratic Party on Tuesday. He will replace the outgoing Sen. Jennifer Veiga, the first openly gay person to serve in the state legislature. She resigned the seat to move to Australia with her partner and her partner's family. Two out of the three finalists in this week's special election to replace Veiga were openly gay, reports The Colorado Independent . >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid85476.asp Congratulations.

content: This is where the generation gap between myself and the Colonel becomes evident. My first reaction upon reading this was, "That's cool, but so what?" It's nice that the people of the state of Focus on the Family are willing to overlook a personal matter like this and elect a man to represent them on merit rather than outward BS - but it isn't a life-altering event for me. It's just the way things should be. It has to do with the different realities we grew up in, I suppose. The Colonel grew up in a time when people that he cared about called him evil and satanic for just such an outward thing. I grew up in a time when people look upon gays with a sense of mild disapproval, but eventually come to realize that gays are individuals no more or less "bad" than society at large. It's a difference in perspective. For me equality is just a matter of time. For him, and his generation, equality is nothing short of a miracle.
